question: You hear about a new business coming to town and you don't approve of the new owners. What do you want to tell the politicians and neighbors?

options.option: This makes me uncomfortable, I vote for single family zoning.
Let's welcome them and make our neighborhood more diverse!
I mind my own business and keep to myself.

question: Single Family Zoning is being argued in the Supreme Court. Luckily you know a few of the Justices and they will listen to your opinion. What do you want to tell them?

options.option: The reasons people live in different types of housing is economic, this zoning segregates people and exclusionary zoning should be struck down.
It's important to protect the character of a neighborhood. If a majority of people in a region want to exclude certain housing types, they should be free to do so.
There's more money to be made in a neighborhood if different housing types are available.  Exclusionary zoning isn't economically smart, strike it down and deem it unconstitutional.
This isn't happening in my town so I don't think it's right for me to have an opinion here.

question: Your coworker bought a plot of land in your neighborhood. They want to split it into two and build four tiny homes - one to live in and 3 to rent out. They are complaining to you that the city won't let them because there is a minimum lot size that a house can be in the region. He asked if you could influence city council to lower the size to allow for a tiny home. What do you want to do?

options.option: Tiny homes are neat, why not? Advocate to get minimum lot size significantly lowered.
Having renters living in tiny homes could change the character of the neighborhood. This doesn't seem like a good idea.
They should have looked into this before buying the land. Sounds like their problem, not mine.
If the minimum lot size is lowered, I could divide my lot in order to build a tiny home for my aging mother to live in. This would help me out too! You advocate for this change.

question: Your friend purchased a brand new 1955 Chevy Bel Air and wants to be sure they can park it for free anywhere in the city. They ask for your help bringing this plan to life. What do you tell city council?

options.option: You don't believe in the city subsidizing free parking. Let the market decide how much parking is built.
You think we can move more people with public transit and don't want to fund free parking.
You have a nice car too and love the idea.  We need as much parking as possible to prevent crowded streets!
